case_name: Anant Prasad Lakshminivas Generiwal v. State of Andhra Pradesh

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 18, 1960, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition No. 358 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.140162. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 18, 1960, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition No. 358 of 1958.

facts.text: Petition No. 86 of 1960 under Art. 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: WITH Petition No. 86 of 1960. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights. C. Chatterjee, Alladi Kuppuswami, T. Rama Chandra Rao and Ganpat Rai, for the

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 2, 1962 by WANCHOO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. November 2. The judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-The appeal is by special leave from the order of the Andhra Pradesh High Court.

facts.text: Appellant is Anant Prasad Lakshminivas Generiwal, sole hereditary trustee and Mutwalli of the temple of Shri Sitaram Maharaj Sansthan and subsidiary deity Shri Varadarajaswami at Sitaram Bagh, Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is Anant Prasad Lakshminivas Generiwal. He is also the petitioner in the writ petition and will hereafter be referred to as the appellant. The main respondents, who are also opposite parties in the writ

facts.text: Main respondents are State of Andhra Pradesh and Director of Endowments, Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: parties in the writ petition, are the State of Andhra Pradesh and the Director of Endowments, Hyderabad. They will be referred to hereinafter as the respondents. The appellant claims to be the sole hereditary trustee

facts.text: Ancestor of appellant migrated to Hyderabad in earlier part of nineteenth century and built temple in or about 1833 costing two lakhs rupees.

anchor.surface_text: In the earlier part of the nineteenth century, an ancestor of the appellant migrated to Hyderabad and carried on business there. He obviously prospered and in or about 1833 he built a temple at a cost of two lakhs of rupees

facts.text: In 1841, Maharaja Chandulal granted jagir of villages Akolee and Bordee in Berar for upkeep of temple.

anchor.surface_text: In 1841, one Maharaja Chandulal, a minister to the then Nizam granted a jagir consisting of the villages of Akolee and Bordee in Berar for the upkeep and maintenance of the temple.

facts.text: Village Bulgaon granted to temple in 1850; Akolee continued in possession.

anchor.surface_text: Later, however, these villages were resumed by the Nizam and two other villages were granted instead to the temple. It appears that these two other villages were also resumed, and the village of Bulgaon was granted to the temple in 1850.

facts.text: In 1853, Berar transferred to British Government by Nizam.

anchor.surface_text: In 1853, Berar was transferred to the British Government of India by the Nizam and these two villages therefore came under the administration of the Government of India.

facts.text: In 1859, title of temple to villages confirmed under Berar Inam Rules; inam certificates issued to Ramlal, son of Hargopal, manager.

anchor.surface_text: In 1859, some doubts arose about the title of the temple to the villages and there were enquiries under the Berar Inam Rules. Eventually, it was decided that the title of the temple was good ... in the name of Ramlal, son of Hargopal, who was described as the Manager

facts.text: In 1932, Lakshminivas Generiwal (father of appellant) decided to be manager of jagirdar, confirmed in 1933 by Governor of Central Provinces.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually, it was decided in 1932 that Lakshminivas Generiwal, father of the appellant, was to be the manager of the jagirdar, and this decision was finally confirmed in 1933 by the Governor of the Central Provinces.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights Act No.1 of 1951 took over two villages, awarded compensation and annual cash grant of Rs. 8,470/- for upkeep.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Madhya Pradesh enacted a law known as the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands Act, No. 1 of 1951. In consequence of this law, the two villages were taken over by the State and statutory compensation was awarded. In addition, an annual cash grant of Rs. 8,470/-

facts.text: Home farm land in two villages yielded income of Rs. 1,30,000/- to trustee.

anchor.surface_text: Besides this grant, there was a large area of home farm land in the two villages, which was in the possession of the trustee for the benefit of the trust, and it is said that an income of Rs. 1,30,000/- was being realised by the trustee from this home farm land.

facts.text: Hereditary pujaris complained of misappropriation by Lakshminivas Generiwal.

anchor.surface_text: It further appears that there are hereditary pujaris and mahants of the temple, and these persons had been complaining to various authorities in Hyderabad that Lakshminivas Generiwal was misappropriating temple funds on a large scale

facts.text: In 1951, three hereditary pujaris filed complaint before Government of Hyderabad alleging mismanagement.

anchor.surface_text: In 1951, three of the hereditary pujaris filed a complaint before the Government of Hyderabad alleging various acts of mismanagement on the part of the trustee.

facts.text: Home Minister directed temple managed by committee of five persons, allegedly with consent of Lakshminivas, who later contested.

anchor.surface_text: This was inquired into by the Home Minister of the State of Hyderabad and he directed that the temple should be managed by a committee of five persons and this was said to have been done with the consent of Lakshminivas Generiwal. Later, however, Lakshminivas contended that he had never consented

facts.text: In March 1956, City Civil Court directed rendition of accounts and appointed auditor who found gross irregularities.

anchor.surface_text: In March, 1956, the court directed rendition of accounts and appointed an auditor to scrutinise them. The auditor- went into the accounts and made a report showing several gross irregularities therein.

facts.text: In June 1955, temple registered as public trust under Madhya Pradesh Public Trusts Act No.30 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime Lakshminivas Generiwal applied for the registration of the temple under the provisions of the Madhya Pradesh Public Trusts Act No. 30 of 1951 and in June, 1955, the Registrar of Public Trusts directed the registration

facts.text: Hyderabad Endowments Regulations came into force in 1940.

anchor.surface_text: This law was known as the Hyderabad Endowments Regulations (hereinafter referred to as the Regulations) and it came into force in 1940.

facts.text: Director of Endowments issued notice to Lakshminivas Generiwal on September 12, 1957 to show cause why removed as trustee, six charges.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of his power under the Regulations and the Rules, the Director of Endowments issued notice to Lakshminivas Generiwal on September 12, 1957, to show cause within a fortnight from the date of the receipt of the notice, why he should not be removed.

facts.text: Lakshminivas replied on September 17, 1957 that son (appellant) appointed trustee by Deputy Commissioner Amravati in November 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Lakshminivas Generiwal replied to this notice on September 17, 1957, and pointed out that he was no longer the trustee and that his son, the appellant, had been appointed the trustee under the Madhya Pradesh Act-, No. 30 of 1951 by order of the Deputy Commissioner Amravati in November 1956.

facts.text: Notice issued to appellant on December 31, 1957 to register temple under Regulations.

anchor.surface_text: On this reply, a notice was issued on December 31, 1957, to the appellant to the effect that the temple had to be registered under the Regulations, and he was also warned that if he failed to take steps to get the endowment registered

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition in Andhra Pradesh High Court on February 3, 1958 challenging notice dated December 31, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Soon after, the appellant filed a writ. petition in the Andhra Pradesh High Court on February 3, 1958, challenging the notice dated December 31, 1957

facts.text: High Court rejected writ petition on March 18, 1960 upholding notice.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court repelled these contentions and by its order dated March 18, 1960, rejected the writ petition, thus upholding the validity of the notice dated December 31, 1957.

facts.text: Director of Endowments passed order on June 13, 1960 to take supervision under r.179.

anchor.surface_text: After the High Court dismissed the writ petition, the Director of Endowments passed two orders. The first is dated June 13, 1960, and it says that as the trustee had not cared to appear before him

facts.text: Order dated June 14, 1960 stated temple taken under supervision of Government of Andhra Pradesh, management vested in Director of Endowments.

anchor.surface_text: The second order was passed on June 14, 1960, and it stated that the temple with its buildings etc. situate at Hyderabad, had been taken under the supervision of the Government of Andhra Pradesh and the management of the temple would vest in the Director of Endowments, Hyderabad, from the date of the order

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: These orders must therefore be set aside as ultra vires the Regulations and the Rules, assuming in the present case that the Regulations and the Rules providing for the removal of the trustee, are constitutional. We therefore dismiss the appeal with costs.

holdings.text: The registration of the trust under the Madhya Pradesh Public Trusts Act No. 30 of 1951 does not exclude the operation of the Hyderabad Endowments Regulations as the temple is situated in Andhra Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore agree with the High Court that the trust in this case being situate in Andhra Pradesh, the Regulations will apply to it. Re.  2 . The contention in this regard is that the Part B

holdings.reasoning_summary: Situs of trust determined by location of temple in Andhra Pradesh per Charusila Dasi; MP Act applies only to trusts in MP.

holdings.text: The Hyderabad Endowments Regulations have not been repealed by the Part B States Laws Act, 1951, as there are no corresponding Central Acts covering religious endowments.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the application of Act XIV of 1920 to the then Part B State of Hyderabad cannot be said to have repealed the Regulations by virtue of s. 6 of the Part B States  Laws  Act, 1951. Re.  3

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charitable Endowments Act excludes religious trusts; 1920 Act limited to accounts inquiry, unlike comprehensive Regulations.

holdings.text: The Regulations are not repugnant to Article 14 as geographical classification in Andhra Pradesh based on historical reasons is valid.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the, attack on the basis of violation of Art. 14 must be repelled in the present case on the authority of Bhaiyalal Shukla's case 1 . Re.  4 . This brings us to the question

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parallel laws in different areas upheld per Bhaiyalal Shukla, distinguishing Rao Manohar; differences arise from history.

holdings.text: Provisions for registration of endowments in the Regulations are reasonable restrictions under Article 19(5) and not violative of Article 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: These Regulations are clearly reasonable restrictions in the interests of the general public within the meaning of Art. 19 (5) of the Constitution and are conceived with the purpose of having correct

holdings.reasoning_summary: Registration ensures proper management and information for public benefit; no opinion on s.4(b) or r.25 as inapplicable.

holdings.text: The orders dated June 13 and 14, 1960, are ultra vires the Regulations and Rules as they amount to removal of trustee without inquiry by competent authority or by Minister.

anchor.surface_text: These orders must therefore be set aside as ultra vires the Regulations and the Rules, assuming in the present case that the Regulations and the Rules providing for the removal of the trustee,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Orders exceed r.179 (supervision); removal requires show cause, inquiry per r.67, by Minister per r.68; s.12 needs finding of incompetence after inquiry.

holdings.text: Under s.12 of the Regulations and rr.67-68, trustee removal requires inquiry by competent officer finding one of six conditions, opportunity to show cause, and order by Minister for Endowments.

anchor.surface_text: Now r. 67 deals with the removal of trustee and has laid down six conditions which would justify the removal of a trustee. The last of these conditions lays down that if any trustee is not

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.12 ('not found to be competent') and rules requires procedural safeguards of natural justice before deprivation of management.

precedents.citation: The State of Bihar v. Smt. Charusila Dasi 1

anchor.surface_text: A similar question came to be considered by this Court in The State of Bihar v. Smt. Charusila Dasi 1 . In that case the temple was situate in Deoghar in the State of Bihar, though the major part of income yielding property endowed to the temple was situate in Calcutta. The question that arose for decision in that case was whether the Bihar law would apply to the temple and its properties.

precedents.case_name: State of Bihar v. Smt. Charusila Dasi
precedents.cited_proposition: Bihar law applies to a temple situated in Bihar even if major income properties are in Calcutta, as the State has legislative power over the trust and trustees within its territory
precedents.cited_holding: where the trust is situate in Bihar the State has legislative power over it and also over its trustees or their servants and agents who must be in Bihar to administer the trust

precedents.citation: State of BihaR v. Bhabapritananda Ojha 1

anchor.surface_text: We may also refer to the State of BihaR v. Bhabapritananda Ojha 1 , where a question was raised with respect to the application of the same Bihar Act to a trust situate in Bihar, but in the case of which a scheme had been framed by the District judge of Burdwan and confirmed by the Calcutta High Court

precedents.case_name: State of Bihar v. Bhabapritananda Ojha
precedents.cited_proposition: Bihar legislature competent to legislate for religious trusts situated in Bihar even if some properties outside and despite prior scheme from another jurisdiction
precedents.cited_holding: it was competent to the Bihar legislature to legislate in respect of religious trusts situate in Bihar though some of the properties belonging to the trust might be outside Bihar

anchor.surface_text: As to where a public trust is situate has to be determined in accordance with the decision of this Court in Smt. Charusila Dasis Case 1 , and on that view the public trust in this case must be situate in Andhra Pradesh and not in Madhya Pradesh where only some of the endowed trust properties are.

precedents.case_name: State of Bihar v. Smt. Charusila Dasi
precedents.cited_proposition: Location of a public trust is determined by where it is situated

precedents.citation: State of Rajasthan v. Rao Manohar Singhji 1

anchor.surface_text: Our attention in this connection has been drawn to the State of Rajasthan v. Rao Manohar Singhji 1 . In that case a law relating to management of jagir estates which applied to only a part of Rajasthan was struck down on the ground that there was nothing corresponding to that law in other parts of Rajasthan

precedents.case_name: State of Rajasthan v. Rao Manohar Singhji
precedents.cited_proposition: Law applying only to part of state without corresponding law elsewhere violates Art. 14 due to discrimination
precedents.cited_holding: there was no real and substantial distinction why the jagirdars of a particular area should continue to be treated with inequality as compared with the jagirdars in another area of Rajasthan

precedents.citation: Bhaiyalal Shukla v. State of Madhya Pradesh 2

anchor.surface_text: As against this, the respondents rely on Bhaiyalal Shukla v. State of Madhya Pradesh 2 . In that case, the sales-tax laws in different parts of the new State of Madhya Pradesh, which came into existence after the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, were different in some respects

precedents.case_name: Bhaiyalal Shukla v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Different but parallel laws in different parts of a reorganized state based on historical reasons do not violate Art. 14
precedents.cited_holding: different though parallel laws in different parts of Madhya Pradesh could be sustained on the ground that the differentiation arose from historical reasons

precedents.citation: Narayan Pershad v. State of Hyderabad 1

anchor.surface_text: We have been told that some of the rules have been the target of attack in the former High Court of Hyderabad, and some of them have been struck down by that High Court see Narayan Pershad v. State of Hyderabad 1 . The sections with respect to registration are s. 3 to s. II.

precedents.case_name: Narayan Pershad v. State of Hyderabad
precedents.cited_proposition: Some rules under the Regulations struck down by Hyderabad High Court
